lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and identify people’s appearances.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Read aloud short appearance descriptions. Students circle the correct face in a worksheet or SB page.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write about their future appearance using key vocabulary and grammar structures from the unit.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Provide frames: “In the future, I will have ___ hair and ___ eyes.” Model writing on board; students complete their version.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can present their future appearance to the class using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Presentation) Students draw their future selves. Say 2–3 full sentences to the class: “I’ll be tall. I’ll have curly hair.”

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
